titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Robert M. Emerson Papers LSC.2211
titlestmt.author: Processed by Kelly Besser with assistance from Kamarin Takahara, 2014. Finding aid prepared by Kelly Besser, 2021.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-06 13:26:19 -0800.

physdesc.extent: (5 document boxes, 2 half size document boxes and 2 record cartons.)

did.abstract: Professor Emeritus Robert M. Emerson has worked for the Department of Sociology at UCLA for 45 years as a leader who was instrumental in building ethnomethodology as a field of inquiry. The collection consists of field notes, subject interview transcripts, academic papers, correspondence, grant proposals, reports and audiovisual recordings of his research projects concerning juvenile court and delinquency labeling, "The Pro Se Litigant: Self-Representation in Consequential Civil Cases," and "Resisting Imposed Relationships" which is also referred to as the Domestic Violence Project (DVP).
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: COLLECTION STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF: Open for research. Advance notice required for access. Contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information. The following materials are restricted for 75 years from the dates listed due to personally identifiable information: Box 2 folder 1 (1966), Box 3-4 (1966), Box 5 folders 4-5, 7, 11(1988), Box 6 folders 3-11(1988) and Box 8 folders 5-51(1989).

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Robert M. Emerson papers (Collection 2211). Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Kelly Besser with assistance from Kamarin Takahara, 2014.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Robert M. Emerson is UCLA Department of Sociology Professor Emeritus. Emerson graduated magna cum laude from Harvard's History Department in 1962 and received his M.A. and Ph.D. in Sociology from Brandeis University in 1964 and 1968. His dissertation is entitled The Juvenile Court: Labeling and Institutional Careers. Emerson began his career at UCLA in 1969 as Assistant Professor in the Department of Sociology, served as Vice Chair and Director of Graduate Studies from 1989-1992, and as Department Chair from 1995-1999. At the conclusion of his chairmanship, he worked as Faculty Director for UCLA's Center for Experiential Education and Service Learning (CEESL) from 2000-2001. Building on the foundational work of UCLA Sociology Professor Harold Garfinkel, Emerson was instrumental in the Department's development of ethnomethodology as a field of inquiry. Emerson is a committed ethnographer and prolific writer who authored numerous publications with fellow ethnomethodologist, UCLA Sociology Professor Melvin Pollner. Emerson's professional activities include work for the Editorial and Publications Committee of the Society for the Study of Social Problems, committee work for the American Sociological Association and editorial service for the following publications: Californian Sociologist, Journal of Contemporary Ethnography, Qualitative Sociology, Social Problems,Symbolic Interaction, Urban Life and Ethnography. Emerson describes his research as using qualitative field methods to examine both the indigenous dynamics of troubles, as in domestic violence situations, stalking and neighbor disputes, and formal, institutional responses to these troubles, particularly by the criminal justice and mental health systems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of field notes, subject interview transcripts, academic papers, correspondence, grant proposals, reports and audiovisual recordings of his research projects concerning juvenile court and delinquency labeling, "The Pro Se Litigant: Self-Representation in Consequential Civil Cases," and "Resisting Imposed Relationships" which is also referred to as the Domestic Violence Project (DVP).

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1: Juvenile court research files. Series 2: Pro se litigant research files. Subseries 2.1: Domestic violence research files. Series 3: Audio visual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Emerson's research files concerning his institutional analysis of a Boston juvenile court and the societal reaction approach to deviance with an emphasis on the labeling process in the court's handling of delinquency. Materials include papers, proposals, historical writings, field notes, lists of offenses and frequencies, probation officer personnel sheets, his signed dissertation, and guidelines and recommended practices for police and probation procedures in juvenile cases.
Box 2, Folder 1: Restricted access and use because of probation officer names and personally identifiable information. This material is closed for 75 years from 1966.
Box 3-4: Restricted access and use because of "juvenile offender" names and personally identifiable information. This material is closed for 75 years from 1966.

did.unittitle: Juvenile court - early papers and proposals.
Documents, historical and personnel materials - BJC.

scopecontent.p: Restricted access and use because of probation officer names and personally identifiable information. This material is closed for 75 years from 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Files regarding Emerson and Dr. Susan M. McCoin's National Science Foundation (NSF) research grant funded project entitled, "The Pro Se Litigant: Self-Representation in Consequential Civil Cases." Materials include correspondence, grant proposals and evaluations, interviews with judges, Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) forms, Instructions for Lawsuits to Prohibit Harassment, Domestic Violence Project TRO forms and instructions, clippings and field notes. The acronym SMSC refers to Santa Monica Superior Court.
Box 5, folders 4-5, 7, 11 and Box 6, folders 3-11: Restricted access and use because of litigant/subject names and personally identifiable information. This material is closed for 75 years from 1988.

did.unittitle: Pro per grant - correspondence, official papers, evaluations.
Pro se grant - budget and administrative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A copy of Guerra's paper, "Court Processing of Temporary Restraining Order Petitions" which includes Emerson's annotations and suggestions for revisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A copy of Robert Garot's paper, "The Separate Worlds of the Courthouse Workgroup and Litigants" which includes Emerson's annotations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abstracts, manuscripts, conference papers and working papers by Emerson and Susan McCoin and NSF proposal evaluation forms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These research files concern Emerson's "Resisting Imposed Relationships" research project which focused on women who have had an unwanted romantic relationship imposed upon them by means of harassment and violence. The proposal grew directly out of Emerson and Susan McCoin's NSF research project, "Self Representation in Consequential Civil Cases." The "Resisting Imposed Relationships" project was also referred to as the Domestic Violence Project (DVP) and focused on the problems people confront in completing applications for domestic violence temporary restraining orders (TROs) and was concerned with the help and support provided by family members, relatives, friends and others, in the decision to seek such restraining orders. The DVP project was funded in 1992 by the UCLA Center for the Study of Women (CSW) mini-grant program established in 1984 to assist faculty with pilot research projects that would ultimately lead to the development of a research proposal for extramural funding. Materials include CSW correspondence and grant application, notes for papers, correspondence with and application to UCLA Human Subject Protection Committee, Torrance domestic violence forms, Torrance Domestic Violence Clinic interviews, Domestic Violence Prevention Act face sheets, TRO coding sheets and field notes.
Box 8, folders 5-51: Restricted access and use because of litigant/subject names and personally identifiable information. This material is closed for 75 years from 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials include audio recordings of field notes, interviews with research project participants and video recordings concerning topics such as kleptomania, multiple personality disorder and troubled kids.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Seventy audio cassette tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Six open reel audio tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Three video cassette tapes.
